content:
You are a reader assistant. You simplify a passage from a scientific paper to make it more readable by performing an iterative algorithm that focuses on atomic changes.

You are also given two parameters: DC (Desired Complexity) – a desired complexity of the simplified text, and ILT (Information Loss Tolerance) – a threshold for information loss compared to original passage that specifies whether an atomic change should be accepted or not.

The algorithm is as follows:
1. Determine if the text is at desired complexity (DC), if yes, terminate the algorithm, else continue.
2. Identify a section of the text whose complexity is above DC.
3. Propose a simplification of the identified section.
4. Identify information loss and the severity of it – if the severity for any of the information loss questions is higher than information loss tolerance (ILT), reject changes, else update the current state of the passage
5. Adjust the passage to maintain readability and flow of text, then run a new iteration of the algorithm.

When the algorithm terminates, you print the original and simplified passages

The passage:
After the automation of many production processes and the creation of self-driving vehicles, the automation of society is next.

DC: University student
ILT: Medium
Identify the complexity level of the passage

The complexity level of the passage is above the desired complexity (DC) for a university student. It contains advanced concepts and implications about automation in society which may require a higher level of understanding. Therefore, this passage is not yet simplified to the desired complexity level.
Is determined complexity higher than DC (University student)? Answer "Yes" or "No"
Yes
Identify a single complicated section of the passage
The section "the automation of society is next" is complicated because it implies a significant and broad concept that encompasses various aspects of daily life and societal functions.
Simplify this section
"The next step is to automate more parts of our daily lives."
Reincorporate the simplified section into the passage
"After the automation of many production processes and the creation of self-driving vehicles, the next step is to automate more parts of our daily lives."
Identify information loss and its severity in the updated passage compared to the original

The information loss from the update involves the omission of the phrase "the automation of society." The simplified version conveys a similar idea but loses some specificity about what aspects of society are being automated. 

Severity of information loss:
1. Clarity: The original clearly refers to "automation of society," which implies a broader and more comprehensive change. The simplified version generalizes this to "automate more parts of our daily lives," which could suggest a narrower focus.
2. Implications: The original implies a significant societal shift, while the simplified version might be interpreted as referring only to routine activities.

The severity of this information loss could be considered medium since it retains the central idea but lessens the impact and scope of the statement.
What is the highest severity level identified? Is it higher than ILT (Medium)? Answer "Yes" or "No"
No
If needed, adjust the passage to maintain readabily and flow of text
"After automating many production processes and creating self-driving vehicles, the next step is to automate more parts of our daily lives."
Identify the complexity level of the passage

The complexity level of the adjusted passage is now appropriate for a university student. It is clearer and more straightforward while still conveying the main idea of automation in society. Therefore, it meets the desired complexity (DC).
Is determined complexity higher than DC (University student)? Answer "Yes" or "No"
No
Provide the final version of the simplified passage

Original Passage: "After the automation of many production processes and the creation of self-driving vehicles, the automation of society is next."

Simplified Passage: "After automating many production processes and creating self-driving vehicles, the next step is to automate more parts of our daily lives."
